galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations module¶

Tools for generic data operations

@author: Zach Hafen @contact: zachary.h.hafen@gmail.com @status: Development

galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.align_axes(arr, new_z_axis, point=array([0., 0., 0.]), align_frame=True)[source]¶

Rotate a series of 3d coordinates s.t. the new z axis is aligned with the input vector new_z_axis

Args:
arr (ndarray):
The coordinates to be rotated. Dimensions must be (n_coords, 3).
new_z_axis (vector arr):
The vector along which the new z axis will be aligned.
point (vector arr):
The point to rotate around. If none, defaults to the origin.
align_frame (bool):
If True, the coordinates are aligned along new_z_axis, but the data keep their same coordinates as before. I.e. we rotate our perspective s.t. new_z_axis is the new z axis. If False, we rotate the data instead, and keep the coordinates the same. I.e. we rotate the data z-axis to be aligned with new_z_axis, but we still view the data from the original perspective. This just changes the sign of the angle of rotation.
Returns:
rotated_arr (ndarray): The rotated array.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.apply_floor(arr, floor)[source]¶

Raises all values in the array below the floor to the floor value.

Args:
arr (np.arr): Array to raise the values of. floor (float): Floor value that will act as the minimum.
Returns:
floored_arr (np.arr): Array with all values below floor set to floor.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.block_mean(arr, fact)[source]¶

Downsample an array

Args:
arr (np.arr): Array to downsample. fact (float): Factor by which to downsample.
Returns:
res (np.arr): Downsampled array.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.cartesian(arrays, out=None)[source]¶

Generate a cartesian product of input arrays. Produced on Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/a/1235363/6651313

Args:
arrays (list of array-like): 1-D arrays to form the cartesian product of. out (ndarray): Array to place the cartesian product in.
Returns:
out (ndarray) 2-D array of shape (M, len(arrays)) containing cartesian products
formed of input arrays.
Examples:
>>> cartesian(([1, 2, 3], [4, 5], [6, 7]))
array([[1, 4, 6],
              [1, 4, 7],
              [1, 5, 6],
              [1, 5, 7],
              [2, 4, 6],
              [2, 4, 7],
              [2, 5, 6],
              [2, 5, 7],
              [3, 4, 6],
              [3, 4, 7],
              [3, 5, 6],
              [3, 5, 7]])
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.contiguous_regions(condition)[source]¶

Finds contiguous True regions of the boolean array “condition”. Returns a 2D array where the first column is the start index of the region and the second column is the end index.

Taken from https://stackoverflow.com/a/4495197

galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.cumsum2d(arr, axes=[0, 1], directions=[1, 1])[source]¶

Get the cumulative sum of an array.

Args:
arr (array-like) :
Array to get the sum of.
axes (list) :
What axes to sum over.
directions (list) :
What direction to sum along.
1 -> standard direction -1 -> reverse direction
Returns:
summed_arr (np.ndarray) :
The i,j element of summed_arr is the sum of arr[:i+1,:j+1]
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.merge_dict(dict1, dict2)[source]¶

Merge two dictionaries, with dict2’s keyword overridding dict1’s keywords when there are duplicates

Args:
dict1 (dict): First dictionary. dict2 (dict): Second dictionary.
Returns:
merged_dict (dict): Merged dictionary.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.rotate_coordinates(arr, angle, axis, point=None)[source]¶

Rotate a series of 3d coordinates clockwise looking down an axis.

Args:
arr (ndarray):
The coordinates to be rotated. Dimensions must be (n_coords, 3).
angle (float):
The angle by which to rotate. Positive means clockwise.
axis (vector arr):
The axis to rotate around.
point (vector arr):
The point to rotate around. If none, defaults to the origin.
Returns:
rotated_arr (ndarray): The rotated array.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.smooth(x, window_len=11, window='flat')[source]¶

Simple moving-window signal smoothing (from scipy cookbook)

Args:
x (1D np.ndarray) :
array to smooth
wind_len (int) :
Number of elements over which to smooth.
window (str) :
Type of window.
Returns:
smoothed_arr (1D np.ndarray) :
Smoothed version of arr.
galaxy_dive.utils.data_operations.smooth_arr(arr, width=20, std=10)[source]¶

Apply a gaussian filter to an array. Credit to Cameron Hummels for the nice simple code I’m using.

Args:
arr (1D np.ndarray) :
array to smooth
width (int) :
Number of elements over which to smooth.
std (int) :
Sigma of the guassian for which to smooth.
Returns:
smoothed_arr (1D np.ndarray) :
Smoothed version of arr.
